title.value: Shedding Light on Large Generative Networks: Estimating Epistemic Uncertainty in Diffusion Models
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the beginning of the paper and in the supplementary section.
title.quote: Shedding Light on Large Generative Networks: Estimating Epistemic Uncertainty in Diffusion Models (Supplementary Material)

extractions.description: This paper presents the Diffusion Ensembles for Capturing Uncertainty (DECU) framework for estimating epistemic uncertainty in diffusion models. Using pre-trained networks and a static set of parameters, the framework creates efficient ensembles of diffusion models, introducing innovations such as Pairwise-Distance Estimators (PaiDEs) to measure uncertainty. The paper evaluates the framework on the ImageNet dataset to demonstrate effectiveness in capturing epistemic uncertainty, especially in under-sampled image classes.

type.justification: The paper introduces an innovative method and assesses its effectiveness through experiments on real datasets, which is characteristic of empirical research.
type.quote: The effectiveness of this framework is demonstrated through experiments on the ImageNet dataset, highlighting its capability to capture epistemic uncertainty, specifically in under-sampled image classes.

name.justification: The paper utilizes image datasets and discusses generative image models, indicating that the primary focus is on Computer Vision.
name.quote: Generative image models play a crucial role in diverse applications, notably in medical image generation and self-driving systems.

name.justification: The paper specifically deals with generative diffusion models to create images and estimate epistemic uncertainty.
name.quote: Generative diffusion models, notable for their large parameter count...

name.justification: The focus of the paper is to address epistemic uncertainty estimation in diffusion models.
name.quote: In this work, we introduce an innovative framework, Diffusion Ensembles for Capturing Uncertainty (DECU), designed for estimating epistemic uncertainty for diffusion models.

name.justification: The paper proposes DECU as a novel framework or model to estimate epistemic uncertainty in diffusion models.
name.quote: We introduce Diffusion Ensembles for Capturing Uncertainty (DECU)...

is_contributed.justification: DECU is explicitly introduced and developed as part of the contributions of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: In this work, we introduce an innovative framework, Diffusion Ensembles for Capturing Uncertainty (DECU)...

is_compared.justification: The paper does not mention direct numerical comparison of DECU with other models; the focus is rather on its development and application.
is_compared.quote: We assess the effectiveness of DECU on image generation...

name.justification: The paper mentions utilizing the latent diffusion framework from Rombach et al. [2022] for constructing diffusion ensembles.
name.quote: We employ the latent diffusion models introduced by Rombach et al. [2022] to construct our ensembles.

referenced_paper_title.justification: No specific reference paper for 'latent-diffusion' is cited directly, but it is associated with the work by Rombach et al., which is used in the framework implementation.
